channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: 3 Sentenced in Germany for Arson Attack Against Refugees
item.description: The judge in the case attributed the actions of the defendants to their radical right-wing, neo-Nazi beliefs.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Robert Fico Retains Power in Slovakia With New Coalition
item.description: Mr. Fico’s party lost its majority in Parliament, but he was able to create a coalition with three parties to form a government.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA

item.title: Matter: Humans Interbred With Hominins on Multiple Occasions, Study Finds
item.description: The interbreeding may have given modern humans better immunity to pathogens, according to the authors of the analysis of global genomes.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: George Osborne Warns of Brexit Risks and Cuts Growth Forecasts
item.description: The British treasury chief also unveiled tax cuts and more resources for education, as well as a tax on sugary drinks, in his annual budget presentation.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, center, visited a construction site for a rail line in central London on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin Declares Syria Operation a Success and Says It’ll Lead to Peace
item.description: The Russian president said that military units could redeploy if needed, while Kurdish leaders unveiled a plan for an autonomous region within a federated Syria.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Vadim Grishankin/Russian Defense Ministry, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A Russian pilot before taking off from Hmeymim air base in Syria on Wednesday. Mr. Putin said the withdrawal of Russian forces would help lead to a negotiated settlement in the conflict.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Denies Letting Gupta Family Pick South Africa’s Ministers
item.description: President Zuma denied accusations that the Guptas, a wealthy family with widespread business interests and links to his own family, had influenced his appointments.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Ramallah Journal: A Legislature Where Palestinian Lawmakers Go to Hide
item.description: The all-but-abandoned Palestinian Parliament building in Ramallah, West Bank, is a haven for legislators avoiding arrest by their own government and Israeli forces.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Najat Abu Baker with activists and relatives who had come to the Palestinian Parliament to support her. The lawmaker hid in the building for 17 days to avoid arrest by her own government.

item.title: Letter From Europe: E.U. Referendum Threatens to Expose Fissures Across Britain
item.description: The gulf between the cosseted south and the industrial north, or between the east and the west, is likely to come under even greater strain.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron, center, spoke last week with employees at a car factory in Ellesmere Port, England, about the benefits of staying in the European Union.

item.title: Meir Dagan, Israeli Spy Chief Who Took Aim at Iran, Dies at 71
item.description: Mr. Dagan was credited with setting back Iran’s nuclear program through covert and daring operations while heading Mossad, Israel’s intelligence agency.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meir Dagan, former director of the Mossad, in New York in 2012. He was the son of Holocaust survivors and immigrated to Israel with his family in 1950.

item.title: Sinosphere: Hong Kong Students Call for Territory’s Independence From China
item.description: A publication by Hong Kong University undergraduates said Beijing was resisting moves toward democracy in the territory and refused to make concessions.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters throwing bricks at the police in the Mong Kok district of Hong Kong on Feb. 9. The clash broke out over a crackdown on street vendors selling snacks that the protesters said were emblematic of local Hong Kong culture.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Patrick Bergin on China’s Role in Protecting Africa’s Wildlife
item.description: Mr. Bergin, the chief executive of the African Wildlife Foundation, a conservation group, says China and its people have a part to play.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A security officer standing guard as contraband elephant ivory seized in Kenya was burned last year.

item.title: Hints in Search for Nefertiti Are Found in Tutankhamen’s Tomb
item.description: Radar scans showed that organic material or metal could be hidden behind the walls, faint clues that the ancient Egyptian queen might be buried there.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The tomb of King Tutankhamen in the Valley of the Kings in Luxor, Egypt, in November.

item.title: Junpei Yasuda, Japanese Journalist Missing in Syria, Surfaces in Video
item.description: Mr. Yasuda is believed to be held by the Nusra Front, an affiliate of Al Qaeda that has taken a number of foreigners.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Junpei Yasuda, a Japanese journalist, in June before leaving for Syria.

item.title: Sinosphere: Giant Maoist Slogans Form Core of Chinese Director’s New Film
item.description: The slogans, visible only from the air, were constructed in 1968, two years after the onset of the decade-long Cultural Revolution.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Cleared earth and gravel form the Maoist slogan “Serve the people,” one of five navigational markings built near a military aviation school in eastern Xinjiang in 1968.

item.title: Kurdish Militants Say They’re Behind Car Bombing in Turkey’s Capital
item.description: The Kurdistan Freedom Hawks said they had carried out the attack in Ankara that killed 37 in retaliation for military operations against rebels.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Riza Ozel/Hurriyet Daily, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene of a car bombing in Ankara, Turkey, on Sunday, that left 37 dead.

item.title: A Journey Across Greece, a Bankrupt Land at Risk of Becoming a Refugee Prison
item.description: More than 44,000 people are already trapped in the country, a number ticking upward each day, as aid groups warn of a potential humanitarian crisis by summer.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: This squalid camp of 12,000 refugees in Idomeni, Greece, is a padlocked waiting room for entering the rest of Europe.

item.title: Editorial: America’s Role in Argentina’s Dirty War
item.description: It is time for the United States to come clean about what it knew and condoned during Argentina’s last dictatorship.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: ‘Big Government’ Looks Great When There Is None
item.description: What Republican candidates consider an American weakness seems like a strength when viewed from South Sudan.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Norwegian Refugee Council compound in Unity State, South Sudan, after looting.

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: Activist’s Colleague Is Killed
item.description: Gunmen killed Nelson García, a colleague of the environmentalist leader Berta Cáceres, who was slain almost two weeks ago under similar circumstances.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea’s History of Seizing Americans
item.description: Roughly a dozen Americans have been held for varying lengths of time by North Korea in the past several years. Most were eventually released.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Otto F. Warmbier, an American college student, was escorted at North Korea’s Supreme Court in Pyongyang on Wednesday. He was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor.
